abstract.text: A modal dialog or sheet attached to a document window.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The methods of the

class allow you to specify alert level, alert text, button titles, and a custom icon should you require it. The class also lets your alerts display a help button and provides ways for apps to offer help specific to an alert.
To display an alert as a sheet, call the
method; to display one as an app-modal dialog, use the
method.
By design, an
object is intended for a single alert—that is, an alert with a unique combination of title, buttons, and so on—that is displayed upon a particular condition. You should create an

object for each alert dialog, creating it only  when you need to display an alert, and release it when you are done. If you have a particular alert dialog that you need to show repeatedly, you can retain and reuse an instance of
for this dialog.
After creating an alert using one of the alert creation methods, you can customize it further prior to displaying it by customizing its attributes. See
Unless you must maintain compatibility with existing alert-processing code that uses the function-based API, you should allocate (
) and initialize (
) the alert object, and then set its attributes using the appropriate methods of the
class.
objects have the following attributes:
Type An alert’s type helps convey the importance or gravity of its message to the user. Specified with the
property.
Message text The main message of the alert. Specified with
Informative text Additional information about the alert. Specified with
Icon An optional, custom icon to display in the alert, which is used instead of the default app icon. Specified with
Help Alerts can let the user get help about them. Use
and
Response buttons By default an alert has one response button: the OK button. You can add more response buttons using the
method.
Suppression checkbox A suppression checkbox allows the user to suppress the display of a particular alert in subsequent occurrences of the event that triggers it. Use
Accessory view An accessory view lets you add additional information to an alert; for example, a text field with contact information. Use
The
class is not designed for subclassing.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A modal dialog or sheet attached to a document window.
The set of alert styles to style alerts in your app.
The alert’s accessory view.
Adds a button with a given title to the alert.
Indicates the alert’s severity level.
Creates an alert compatible with alerts created using the
function for display as a warning-style alert.
Runs the alert modally as a sheet attached to the specified window.
Runs the alert modally as an alert sheet attached to a specified window.
The array of response buttons for the alert.
The alert’s delegate.
The alert’s HTML help anchor.
The custom icon displayed in the alert.
The alert’s informative text.
Returns an alert initialized from information in an error object.
Specifies that the alert must do immediate layout instead of lazily just before display.
The alert’s message text or title.
Runs the alert as an app-modal dialog and returns the constant that identifies the button clicked.
Specifies whether the alert has a help button.
Specifies whether the alert includes a suppression checkbox, which you can employ to allow a user to opt out of seeing the alert again.
The alert’s suppression checkbox.
The app-modal panel or document-modal sheet that corresponds to the alert.
A set of optional methods implemented by the delegate of an
object to respond to a user’s request for help.
A set of button return values for modal dialogs.
Creates an alert panel.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
